    Continuous Data Table

    Kyle Baron

    2020-07-31

    continuous-table.Rmd

    These functions create summary tables for continuous data. There is a long format and a wide format.

    Long format

    library(pmtables)
library(dplyr)

id <- pmtables:::data("id")

    A summary of covariates

    pt_cont_long(id, cols = "WT,ALB,SCR")
. $data
. # A tibble: 3 x 6
.   Variable     n Mean  Median SD    `Min / Max` 
.   <chr>    <int> <chr> <chr>  <chr> <chr>       
. 1 WT         157 70.7  70.0   12.8  43.6 / 97.2 
. 2 ALB        156 4.20  4.32   0.793 1.28 / 5.39 
. 3 SCR        160 1.36  1.04   0.986 0.710 / 5.59
. 
. $align
. $complete
. NULL
. 
. $default

    Paneled summary

    Use the panel argument to split this by, for example, study

    pt_cont_long(
  id, 
  cols = "WT,ALB,SCR",
  panel = vars(Study = STUDYf)
)
. $data
. # A tibble: 15 x 7
.    STUDYf      Variable     n Mean  Median SD    `Min / Max` 
.    <chr>       <chr>    <int> <chr> <chr>  <chr> <chr>       
.  1 12-DEMO-001 WT          29 72.2  70.0   14.3  50.9 / 97.2 
.  2 12-DEMO-001 ALB         29 4.28  4.08   0.474 3.56 / 5.15 
.  3 12-DEMO-001 SCR         30 1.03  1.04   0.155 0.740 / 1.30
.  4 12-DEMO-002 WT          49 72.4  72.1   11.5  51.5 / 96.6 
.  5 12-DEMO-002 ALB         50 4.47  4.43   0.468 3.65 / 5.39 
.  6 12-DEMO-002 SCR         50 0.971 0.970  0.161 0.720 / 1.30
.  7 11-DEMO-005 WT          39 68.9  65.4   14.5  43.6 / 92.8 
.  8 11-DEMO-005 ALB         39 4.41  4.44   0.537 3.51 / 5.39 
.  9 11-DEMO-005 SCR         40 2.52  2.33   1.43  0.720 / 5.59
. 10 13-DEMO-001 WT          40 69.4  68.1   11.6  50.7 / 96.6 
. 11 13-DEMO-001 ALB         38 3.58  3.65   1.15  1.28 / 5.38 
. 12 13-DEMO-001 SCR         40 0.950 0.975  0.165 0.710 / 1.26
. 13 All data    WT         157 70.7  70.0   12.8  43.6 / 97.2 
. 14 All data    ALB        156 4.20  4.32   0.793 1.28 / 5.39 
. 15 All data    SCR        160 1.36  1.04   0.986 0.710 / 5.59
.

    Wide format

    There is also a wide format, where variable names go across the table.

    pt_cont_wide(id, cols = "WT,ALB,SCR")
. $data
. # A tibble: 1 x 3
.   WT                ALB                SCR               
.   <chr>             <chr>              <chr>             
. 1 70.7 (12.8) [157] 4.20 (0.793) [156] 1.36 (0.986) [160]
. 
. $align
. $complete
. NULL
. 
. $default
. [1] "l"
. 
. $update
. list()
. 
. $coltype
. [1] "p"
. 
. $outer
. [1] "none"
. 
. attr(,"class")

. attr(,"class")
. [1] "pmtable"

    We can use the by argument here

    pt_cont_wide(id,cols="WT,ALB,SCR",by = vars(Study = STUDYf))
. $data
. # A tibble: 5 x 4
.   Study                         WT              ALB              SCR            
.   <chr>                         <chr>           <chr>            <chr>          
. 1 "12-DEMO-001"                 72.2 (14.3) [2â€¦ 4.28 (0.474) [2â€¦ 1.03 (0.155) [â€¦

    Or use by and panel

    pt_cont_wide(
  id,
  cols=vars(WT,ALB,SCR),
  by = vars(Study = STUDYf),
  panel=vars(Sex = SEXf)
)
. $data
. # A tibble: 9 x 4
.   SEXf     WT                ALB                SCR               
.   <chr>    <chr>             <chr>              <chr>             
. 1 male     76.3 (16.8) [10]  4.33 (0.468) [10]  1.09 (0.174) [10] 
. 2 male     71.9 (13.4) [17]  4.57 (0.497) [18]  1.01 (0.182) [18] 
. 3 male     69.2 (15.0) [29]  4.46 (0.543) [29]  2.51 (1.46) [29]  
. 4 male     71.1 (13.3) [23]  3.68 (1.01) [22]   0.922 (0.163) [23]
. 5 female   70.0 (12.8) [19]  4.25 (0.488) [19]  1.01 (0.141) [20] 
. 6 female   72.6 (10.6) [32]  4.42 (0.450) [32]  0.949 (0.146) [32]
. 7 female   67.9 (13.3) [10]  4.26 (0.516) [10]  2.53 (1.43) [11]  
. 8 female   67.0 (8.74) [17]  3.45 (1.35) [16]   0.988 (0.164) [17]
. 9 All data 70.7 (12.8) [157] 4.20 (0.793) [156] 1.36 (0.986) [160]
.
